item.title: Japan 40-Year Bond Sale Has Weakest Demand Since July
item.description: Japan’s auction of 40-year government bonds Wednesday met demand that was the weakest since July, an outcome that risks fueling further volatility in global debt markets.
item.dc:creator: Mia Glass, Ayai Tomisawa

item.title: China Plans Commodities Overhaul to Attract Global Investors
item.description: China is on the cusp of its biggest move yet to open up its vast commodities markets, after the Shanghai Futures Exchange unveiled an internationalization plan to streamline access for overseas investors.
item.dc:creator: Martin Ritchie, Winnie Zhu

item.title: Raghuram Rajan Warns US Risks Future by Curbing Foreign Students
item.description: Former Reserve Bank of India Governor Raghuram Rajan warned about the long-term risks to the US economy if politics eroded the pipeline of international students to American universities.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Cyberattack Surge Creates Opportunity for Insurers, Prompts Rethink on Premiums
item.description: A recent surge in high-profile cyberattacks is offering an opportunity for insurers including Munich Re AG and Chubb Ltd. to cash in from a rapidly expanding market — and prompting a rethink on premiums.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Shiltagh, Chloe Meley

item.title: US Issues Limited License for Chevron to Continue in Venezuela
item.description: The Trump administration issued a stripped-down license to Chevron Corp. to remain in Venezuela, allowing the company to conduct minimal maintenance on equipment but prohibiting it from producing oil in the sanctioned South American nation.
item.dc:creator: Eric Martin

item.title: Treasuries Hold Drop After Weak Japan Bond Auction: Markets Wrap
item.description: Treasuries held their decline after a highly-watched sale of 40-year bonds in Japan saw its weakest demand since July.
item.dc:creator: Anand Krishnamoorthy

media:content.media:description: The Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE) building, operated by Japan Exchange Group Inc. (JPX), in Tokyo, Japan, on Wednesday, April 9, 2025. Japanese stocks tumbled as concerns about US trade tariffs and wild swings on Wall Street sapped investor confidence, while the yen extended its rally.

item.title: China Steel Woes Deepen as Rebar Prices Fall to Eight-Year Low
item.description: Prices of a key Chinese steel product used in construction were at their lowest since 2017 as the world’s biggest market for the metal grappled with a massive glut.
item.dc:creator: Annie Lee, Katharine Gemmell

item.title: Bloomberg: The Asia Trade 05/28/2025
item.description: "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade" brings you everything you need to know to get ahead as the trading day begins in Asia. Bloomberg TV is live from Sydney with Paul Allen and Haidi Stroud-Watts, getting insight and analysis from newsmakers and industry leaders on the biggest stories shaping global markets. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Japan’s Taiyo Gets Buyout Proposals From Firms Including KKR
item.description: Japanese chemical manufacturer Taiyo Holdings Co. has received acquisition proposals from two companies including US investment firm KKR & Co., according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Takako Taniguchi, Taro Fuse, Hideki Suzuki

item.title: US-Sanctioned Tankers Seen in Russia-to-India Crude Oil Trade
item.description: US-sanctioned tankers have emerged in the complex maritime supply chain that ferries Russian oil to India, raising questions about the Asian nation’s stance toward the flows just as imports hit a record.
item.dc:creator: Weilun Soon, Rakesh Sharma

media:content.media:description: Viktor Titov, a US-sanctioned tanker (marked in white) recently transfered its Russian crude cargo to Night Glory (blue), which then moved those barrels to Cordelia Moon (orange). This third tanker then delivered them to India last week.

item.title: Dalio Won’t Join Indonesia Wealth Fund Danantara as Adviser
item.description: Ray Dalio won’t be an adviser to Indonesia’s new sovereign wealth fund Danantara, people familiar with the matter said, just two months after officials announced the billionaire’s involvement.
item.dc:creator: Jun Luo

media:content.media:description: Ray Dalio Photographer: Victor J. Blue/Bloomberg

item.title: SpaceX Starship Fails in Fiery Test Setback
item.description: SpaceX's Starship rocket suffered a leak, lost control, and disintegrated during a test flight on Tuesday, marking the company's third setback in a row. Bloomberg's Paul Allen shares what we know so far. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Brazil Sues EV Giant BYD Over ‘Slavery’ Conditions at Plant
item.description: Brazilian labor prosecutors are suing Chinese electric vehicle maker BYD Co. and two contractors over allegations of slave labor and human trafficking at the construction site of a manufacuturing plant.
item.dc:creator: Leonardo Lara

item.title: Indian Stock Bulls Count on June For Sustained Gains
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Alex Gabriel Simon

item.title: UBS APAC President Khan on Strategy, Rates & Volatility
item.description: Wealthy clients of UBS are looking to buy more alternative assets as they seek to diversify investments during a volatile period. From the sidelines of the 28th 'Asian Investment Conference', UBS Asia Pacific President & Co-President Global Wealth Management Iqbal Khan also said that that he expects volatility to continue and rates to come down. Khan speaks exclusively to Bloomberg's David Ingles in Hong Kong. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: China Seeks to Slow Yuan’s Gains After Months of Propping It Up
item.description: The dollar’s extended slide has prompted China’s central bank to change tack in managing its currency, as it pivots from supporting the yuan to guarding against the risk of a rapid appreciation.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Wenjin Lv, Ran Li

item.title: Hong Kong Asks Pensions to Form Plans In Case of US Rating Tweak
item.description: Hong Kong officials told the city’s pension funds to formulate appropriate strategies in the event of “any significant market events” regarding the credit rating of the US government debt.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ritchie, Echo Wong

media:content.media:description: A man waits to board a Star Ferry Co. vessel, owned by Wharf Holdings Ltd., in the Tsim Sha Tsui district of Hong Kong, China, on Wednesday, May 28, 2014. The Star Ferry Co., founded in 1898, is a passenger ferry service operator which carries people back and forth across Victoria Harbour. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

item.title: Link Asset Management CEO on Business Strategy
item.description: George Hongchoy, Executive Director and Group CEO at Link Asset Management, discusses the company’s latest earnings and business strategy. He speaks with Paul Allen and Haidi Stroud-Watts on “Bloomberg: The Asia Trade”. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Advances in Risk-On Mood Ahead of OPEC+ Committee Meeting
item.description: Oil rose alongside equity markets ahead of an OPEC+ committee meeting, while traders monitor the prospect for more US sanctions on Russia.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen

media:content.media:description: A storage tank at an oil refinery operated by Bharat Petroleum Corp. Ltd., in Mumbai, India, on Friday, April 4, 2025. Indian refiners have rushed back to the market to seek crude supply after President Donald Trump’s threat of more penalties against Russia raised concerns over potential disruptions to oil flows. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: Fed’s Williams Says Pandemic Changed Inflation Expectations
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of New York President John Williams says pandemic-era price shocks have changed American consumers' inflation perceptions. He speaks at a Bank of Japan conference in Tokyo. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: China Bank Touted Wall Street Internship for $1 Million Deposit
item.description: As Chinese banks battle for deposits amid sinking interest rates, one lender, briefly, took a novel approach to win business: It offered help in securing internships at some of the nation’s biggest companies as well as Wall Street banks for families who put in more than $1 million.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Zheng Li, Amanda Wang

item.title: Traders Brace for Japan 40-Year Bond Sale After Yields Swoon
item.description: Investors are on tenterhooks Wednesday for an auction of 40-year Japanese government bonds as volatility in the nation’s yields continues to rumble through global debt markets.
item.dc:creator: Mia Glass

item.title: India Bonds Are a Buy for Citi on Diverging Rates Policy With US
item.description: The rally in Indian bonds is set to extend as the nation embarks on deeper interest-rate cuts, diverging from the US, according to Citigroup Inc.
item.dc:creator: Bhaskar Dutta, Ruth Carson

item.title: Fed’s Williams Says Pandemic Changed Inflation Perceptions
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of New York President John Williams said pandemic-era price shocks changed American consumers’ inflation perceptions, and policymakers can’t take for granted that people’s estimates of future price increases will remain anchored.
item.dc:creator: Maria Eloisa Capurro, Toru Fujioka

item.title: UBS’s Khan Sees Rich Customer Demand for Alternative Assets
item.description: Wealthy customers of UBS Group AG are looking to buy more alternative assets as they seek to diversify investments during a volatile period for markets and global trade, according to the firm’s Asia Pacific chief.
item.dc:creator: Denise Wee, David Ingles

item.title: Chinese Stock Market in Limbo as Investors Lack Conviction
item.description: Chinese stocks have been notably calm during the recent bout of global market volatility, as investors opt to stay on the sidelines until there is clarity on tariffs and domestic stimulus.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Lin Zhu, April Ma

item.title: Sultan of Brunei Hospitalized in Malaysia for Fatigue
item.description: Brunei’s Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah was hospitalized in Kuala Lumpur on Tuesday due to fatigue, according to an official statement.
item.dc:creator: Ram Anand

media:content.media:description: Sultan of Brunei Hassanal Bolkiah, center, during the 2nd ASEAN-Gulf Cooperation Council Summit after the 46th Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Summit in Kuala Lumpur on May 27.

item.title: Gold Edges Higher After Loss With US Data, Trade Talks in Focus
item.description: Gold edged higher after a two-day decline, as the market remained in wait-and-see mode in spite of data showing improving economic sentiment and signs of progress in trade talks.
item.dc:creator: Sybilla Gross

media:content.media:description: A gold bar, part of the Czech National Bank's reserves arranged in Prague, Czech Republic, on Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2025. Gold’s recent record-breaking run has been broadly supported by haven demand, amid concern and increasing confusion over US President Donald Trump’s plan to enact sweeping tariffs.

item.title: Malaysia to Benefit as Global Funds Pare Exposure to US
item.description: CIMB Group CEO Novan Amirudin believes Malaysia could be a top emerging market beneficiary if Trump's trade policies hit US assets, stating the country 'ticks the boxes for investors.' He exclusively spoke with Bloomberg's Avril Hong on the sidelines of the ASEAN summit in Kuala Lumpur. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Malaysia Sees US Reducing Proposed Tariff to 10%
item.description: The US reducing its proposed tariffs on Malaysia to a 10% baseline would be seen as a positive move, Investment, Trade and Industry Minister Zafrul Azizsaid, conceding that a previously hoped for levy of zero may not be possible. He spoke to Bloomberg's Avril Hong on the sidelines of Asean summit in Kuala Lumpur. (Source: Bloomberg)
